content.body: abarth, Hixie: the specs themselves do not say anything about deleting the other spec from the universe
abarth, Hixie: thus, by proposing to advance both, the chair in question has sort of decided the controversy
yes, although that might have been before tyler and mark make their "UM and no CORS" position clear
i failed to refrain from posting on that thread :(
I can't even bring myself to read the latest emails right now
but I think I will personally try not to post unless I have new information to add

roc, BTW, <https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=535043>.  Do you know what kind of ballpark response time I should expect?  There seem to be 53 bugs with review requested from jst, some years old.
try asking for an ETA in the bug
Is he automatically CCed?
no, good point
CC him
k, thanks.
Is there any semantic value to @class?
Or is it purely a connection to style?
GPHemsley: is that a trick question?
um... no?
OK, it seems clear it does have semantic value
though I wouldn't be surprised to find somebody dispute that for whatever reason
so then it can be used (semantically) in lieu of an element that doesn't exist in the standard?
yeah, that's part of the intent
right, OK
thanks
but the semantics and style often go hand-in-hand
well, yes and no
that's why I qualified it with "often"..
I mean, if something were fed a pure HTML5 document and was asked to extract the data, the styling wouldn't matter
true that
but on the other hand, if some part of you content means something different you often want to dislay it to users differently
and, in that case, <var> and <span class="expression"> (for example) would hold the same weight, correct?
no, I don't think so
<var> has a standard, documented meaning
class="expression" means whatever you choose it to mean, and nobody else can know for sure what you mean by it
well, assume that the meaning of each class was documented and used standardly
OK
also, all that said, you could also misuse <var> in a way that's at odd with with its standard meaning
right
this situation, however, assumes that whatever is doing the processing knows what everything means and expects everything to be used as defined
so it expects <var> to be used correctly
(and also <span class="expression">)
...you can't nest <span>s?
or Firefox can't... o_0
oh, nope, my mistake
is an idiot
(overzealous find and replace)
Weeeâ€¦ Opera 10.50 pre-alpha shipped.
</mindlessspam>
gsnedders, AV-enabled?
erlehmann: Coming soon
needs more theora. :3
gsnedders, new JS engine looks interesting :)
doublec: Of course, it's what I've been working on ;P
haha, nice. I'm hearing good stuff about it on reddit and places
i'll have to try my 8080 emulator on it
Does Opera give any hints on what sort of general approach or techniques they used in the new JS engine?
hsivonen: http://my.opera.com/core/blog/2009/02/04/carakan ?
Rik`: thanks
wonders if Opera still intends to keep Futhark around for small devices
hsivonen: http://my.opera.com/core/blog/2009/12/22/carakan-revisited
thanks
doublec: iirc your 8080 emulator claims that we don't support canvas
(so it would be nice if you would fix that :)

BTW if anyone is playing with the labs build and finds a site that breaks in a likely-javascript related way and doesn't want to file a bug for some reason (e.g. laziness), please let gsnedders or I know
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/337 - Opera 10.50 seems quite nicely fast at that
(I get about 14 million ints/sec, vs about 2 M/sec in Firefox 3.5, and approximately zero in Opera 10.10)
(Though with holidays I dunno how we'll be around)
jgraham: I detect for createImageData and display the message if it doesn't exist
jgraham: does Opera not support it?
doublec: It does
odd -I wonder why it fails
The announcement for Selectors API being published as CR should come out some time later today
gsnedders: document.getElementById('screen').getContext('2d').createImageData is undefined
gsnedders: that's why the 8080 emulator is not running
gsnedders: tested in 10.50 pre-alpha using the js command line
gsnedders: 'screen' is a <canvas id='screen'>
doublec: Does it work in 10.10?
gsnedders: I'll check
doublec: Or does it work with JIT disabled?
That seems really like a normal JIT bug :)
(Namely, random things being undefined)
gsnedders: how do I disable the jit?
doublec: opera:config, search for JIT
gsnedders: doesn't work in 10.10 either
gsnedders: on 10.5 with jit disabled same issue
doublec: Link to the page?
gsnedders: http://www.bluishcoder.co.nz/js8080/
Oh, apparently we don't sup[port it.
*support
that'll be it then :)
gsnedders, what in-joke is that with the power plants mentioned in the caveat?
huh?
First reply from uni application! A rejection!
(I suck at CS.)

Hi.  Is the validator.nu validator known to be broken in trunk?  I'm get a ClassCastException when running it and before I spend too much time tracking it down, wanted to make sure others weren't already aware of it.
Hmm . . . I found IRC logs highlighting the same issue going back to May.
Alright.  If I run "all" a second time, it works.
Repeatable, too.
gsnedders: s'ton?
nirvdrum: try rerunning python build.py localent
hsivonen: I hadn't run localent explicitly at all.  I just ran the "all" target.  Re-running that fixes the problem.
I'll see if "localent" after "all" fixes it, too, but it might be hard to tell.
hsivonen: I don't suppose there's any way to build a WAR out of this, is there?
nirvdrum: there isn't, because I haven't needed a WAR
I couldn't quite work out how you were serving out of jetty.  Where is the web context being set up?
Main.java
in the validator svn repo
afk
So, I guess I could write something to unpack the validator JAR and set up the WAR structure, adding in the dependencies to WEB-INF/lib.
It'd just be handy to have a WAR because I'm already running Jetty and the CSS validator on the same machine.

hsivonen: My other question is if I run it with th "run" target, how do you recommend detaching from the tty and capturing the pid?  I could do it with nohup and some bash incantation, but I'd assume there's a cleaner way.
hsivonen: all => localent => run still induces the CCE.
